content: #ImWithHer, but she has to show up first. self-doubt is driving the gender gap in political ambition Lucero CantuBlockedUnblockFollowFollowingMar 30 Photo by Element5 Digital on Unsplash Here’s what this isn’t going to be: a women-blaming rant, ignorant of the very real barriers women must catapult themselves over to be successful. Instead, I think it’s important to counter the idea that most people don’t want to elect women just because they’re women. In fact, women are just as likely to win a campaign as men. This may go against the pervasive narratives we adopt as fact, but the large gender division in our political institutions is not due to sex discrimination. The problem isn’t that women don’t win enough campaigns, but rather that not enough women run, to begin with. Girls Just Wanna Not Run is a policy report by researchers at American University and Loyola Marymount University. The 2013 publication examined the tendency for women to fall into an ambition gap when it comes to pursuing political careers. 2,100 female college students aged 18–25 were surveyed in this study. Ultimately researchers found that as women are entering their first careers there is already a noticeable gap in women positioning themselves for political futures. The researchers went beyond these findings to identify five factors that contribute to the political ambition gender gap, they argue that: Young men are more likely than young women to be socialized by their parents to think about politics as a career path.From their school experiences to their peer associations to their media habits, young women tend to be exposed to less political information and discussion than do young men.Young men are more likely than young women to have played organized sports and care about winning.Young women are less likely than young men to receive encouragement to run for office — from anyone.Young women are less likely than young men to think they will be qualified to run for office, even once they are established in their careers. So, before we bombard this general study with our personal anecdotes claiming the exact opposite, let’s discuss these factors a little more closely. The first thing you’ll notice is that the first four factors can be summed up to socialization. The way we interact with girls and the expectations we place upon them do impact their levels of confidence, ambition, and resilience. I think a lot of us like to believe we’re above being socialized into certain behaviors, I know I used to fall into this category. Women aren’t conditioned and propped up as senators, governors, or presidents. No one tells them they’re destined to be master negotiators and while some bro can pout in the corner and say that “if you’re a true leader, no one should have to tell you,” I’d argue that’s only half true. The reality is that no matter how strong you are if that strength and intellect is constantly beaten down — you will eventually start to “correct” yourself in some way, shape, or form. If you have the innate abilities of a leader, they will begin to shine. If people constantly press against that inner ability and label confident as “bossy,” decisive as “bitchy,” and strong as “too loud” that ability will begin to dissipate. Outspoken boys are future politicians, outspoken girls are know-it-alls. Moving on to the fifth factor, I can’t help but think of the infamous Hewlett Packard internal report that found that on average men apply for a job when they meet roughly 60% of the qualifications whereas women apply for jobs only when they meet 100%. Personally, I’ve been working on myself to correct this behavior. It seems to be very common for women to try to get everything “right” before jumping into any sort of risky endeavor. About two years ago, I met Kristin Jones, former Director of Special Projects for Michelle Obama. She acknowledged this point by saying, “We’re so busy prepping ourselves to be prepared to be at the table that we miss seats.” While the fear of taking a risk and falling flat on our faces is gender-neutral, it is important that we realize that women seem to be more deeply affected by risk-taking than men. Obviously, I’m speaking in generalities but since this behavior needs to be acknowledged to build equal representation among the general population, I think we’re okay. This study should function as a to-do list rather than a sad reflection of the status-quo. Personally, I am naturally competitive and I’ve grown out of my cautionary, self-doubt phase. I also know a lot of politically ambitious women through my networks with IGNITE National and the American Conservation Coalition. These women are not only intelligent and ambitious, but they also take the time to lift up other women. That’s what we should all be doing. The only way we will achieve gender parity in politics is through the relentless encouragement and mentoring of young women. We don’t have to teach women to be leaders, most of them already are. We have to teach women to trust their instincts and trust in their ability to lead.
title: #ImWithHer, but she has to show up first.
content_html:
#ImWithHer, but she has to show up first.

self-doubt is driving the gender gap in political ambition

Lucero Cantu
Mar 30

Here’s what this isn’t going to be: a women-blaming rant, ignorant of the very real barriers women must catapult themselves over to be successful. Instead, I think it’s important to counter the idea that most people don’t want to elect women just because they’re women.

In fact, women are just as likely to win a campaign as men. This may go against the pervasive narratives we adopt as fact, but the large gender division in our political institutions is not due to sex discrimination.

The problem isn’t that women don’t win enough campaigns, but rather that not enough women run, to begin with.

Girls Just Wanna Not Run is a policy report by researchers at American University and Loyola Marymount University. The 2013 publication examined the tendency for women to fall into an ambition gap when it comes to pursuing political careers.

2,100 female college students aged 18–25 were surveyed in this study. Ultimately researchers found that as women are entering their first careers there is already a noticeable gap in women positioning themselves for political futures.

The researchers went beyond these findings to identify five factors that contribute to the political ambition gender gap, they argue that:

  1. Young men are more likely than young women to be socialized by their parents to think about politics as a career path.
  2. From their school experiences to their peer associations to their media habits, young women tend to be exposed to less political information and discussion than do young men.
  3. Young men are more likely than young women to have played organized sports and care about winning.
  4. Young women are less likely than young men to receive encouragement to run for office — from anyone.
  5. Young women are less likely than young men to think they will be qualified to run for office, even once they are established in their careers.

So, before we bombard this general study with our personal anecdotes claiming the exact opposite, let’s discuss these factors a little more closely.

The first thing you’ll notice is that the first four factors can be summed up to socialization. The way we interact with girls and the expectations we place upon them do impact their levels of confidence, ambition, and resilience. I think a lot of us like to believe we’re above being socialized into certain behaviors, I know I used to fall into this category.

Women aren’t conditioned and propped up as senators, governors, or presidents. No one tells them they’re destined to be master negotiators and while some bro can pout in the corner and say that “if you’re a true leader, no one should have to tell you,” I’d argue that’s only half true.

The reality is that no matter how strong you are if that strength and intellect is constantly beaten down — you will eventually start to “correct” yourself in some way, shape, or form. If you have the innate abilities of a leader, they will begin to shine. If people constantly press against that inner ability and label confident as “bossy,” decisive as “bitchy,” and strong as “too loud” that ability will begin to dissipate.

Outspoken boys are future politicians, outspoken girls are know-it-alls.

Moving on to the fifth factor, I can’t help but think of the infamous Hewlett Packard internal report that found that on average men apply for a job when they meet roughly 60% of the qualifications whereas women apply for jobs only when they meet 100%.

Personally, I’ve been working on myself to correct this behavior. It seems to be very common for women to try to get everything “right” before jumping into any sort of risky endeavor. About two years ago, I met Kristin Jones, former Director of Special Projects for Michelle Obama. She acknowledged this point by saying,

“We’re so busy prepping ourselves to be prepared to be at the table that we miss seats.”

While the fear of taking a risk and falling flat on our faces is gender-neutral, it is important that we realize that women seem to be more deeply affected by risk-taking than men. Obviously, I’m speaking in generalities but since this behavior needs to be acknowledged to build equal representation among the general population, I think we’re okay.

This study should function as a to-do list rather than a sad reflection of the status-quo. Personally, I am naturally competitive and I’ve grown out of my cautionary, self-doubt phase. I also know a lot of politically ambitious women through my networks with IGNITE National and the American Conservation Coalition.

These women are not only intelligent and ambitious, but they also take the time to lift up other women. That’s what we should all be doing. The only way we will achieve gender parity in politics is through the relentless encouragement and mentoring of young women.

We don’t have to teach women to be leaders, most of them already are. We have to teach women to trust their instincts and trust in their ability to lead.

#ImWithHer, but she has to show up first.

self-doubt is driving the gender gap in political ambition

Lucero Cantu
Mar 30

Here’s what this isn’t going to be: a women-blaming rant, ignorant of the very real barriers women must catapult themselves over to be successful. Instead, I think it’s important to counter the idea that most people don’t want to elect women just because they’re women.

The way we interact with girls and the expectations we place upon them do impact their levels of confidence, ambition, and resilience. The reality is that no matter how strong you are if that strength and intellect is constantly beaten down — you will eventually start to “correct” yourself in some way, shape, or form. If you have the innate abilities of a leader, they will begin to shine. If people constantly press against that inner ability and label confident as “bossy,” decisive as “bitchy,” and strong as “too loud” that ability will begin to dissipate.

Moving on to the fifth factor, I can’t help but think of the infamous Hewlett Packard internal report that found that on average men apply for a job when they meet roughly 60% of the qualifications whereas women apply for jobs only when they meet 100%.

Personally, I’ve been working on myself to correct this behavior. It seems to be very common for women to try to get everything “right” before jumping into any sort of risky endeavor. About two years ago, I met Kristin Jones, former Director of Special Projects for Michelle Obama. She acknowledged this point by saying,

“We’re so busy prepping ourselves to be prepared to be at the table that we miss seats.”

While the fear of taking a risk and falling flat on our faces is gender-neutral, it is important that we realize that women seem to be more deeply affected by risk-taking than men. Obviously, I’m speaking in generalities but since this behavior needs to be acknowledged to build equal representation among the general population, I think we’re okay.

This study should function as a to-do list rather than a sad reflection of the status-quo. Personally, I am naturally competitive and I’ve grown out of my cautionary, self-doubt phase. I also know a lot of politically ambitious women through my networks with IGNITE National and the American Conservation Coalition.

These women are not only intelligent and ambitious, but they also take the time to lift up other women. That’s what we should all be doing. The only way we will achieve gender parity in politics is through the relentless encouragement and mentoring of young women.

We don’t have to teach women to be leaders, most of them already are. We have to teach women to trust their instincts and trust in their ability to lead.
